paragraph.docTitle:
trans -Tiliroside: A potent α -glucosidase inhibitor from the leaves of
Elaeagnus angustifolia L

subSection.paragraph:
Hafize Yuca
a, b, *
, Hilal ¨Ozbek a, b , Lütfiye ¨Omür Demirezer c , Handan G¨okben Kasil a , Zühal Güvenalp a, b

docAuthorAffiliation.docAuthorEmail: Department of Pharmacognosy , Faculty of Pharmacy , Ataturk University , 25240, Erzurum , Turkey

subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO

collectionCode.name: Department of Botany, Swedish Museum of Natural History

subSection.paragraph:
Elaeagnus angustifolia L
. ( Elaeagnaceae ) is an important medicinal plant associated with numerous pharmacological activities. Its leaves are used as a therapeutic agent in traditional medicinal systems to treat diabetes. However, the active compounds responsible for the beneficial effects of
E. angustifolia
remain unclear. In this study, we determined the bioactive profile of
E. angustifolia
leaves using open column chromatography and semi-preparative HPLC. Further, we sought to determine its α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities, and its DPPH and ABTS radical-scavenging activities. Four undescribed flavonol glycosides, igdoside A–D, and four known glucosides were isolated from the ethyl acetate and n -butanol extracts of
E. angustifolia
leaves. Thereafter, the compound structures were identified using spectroscopic methods, including NMR and mass spectrometry. Of the compounds extracted, kaempferol-3- O -(6 ′′ - trans -p -coumaroyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( trans -tiliroside), exhibited the highest α -glucosidase inhibitory activity with an IC 50 value of 2128 ± 63 μM compared to the positive control, acarbose (IC 50 = 6561 ± 207 μM). trans -Tiliroside was also found to exhibit potent scavenging activity against the ABTS radical, with an IC 50 value of 5 ± 0 μM, compared to the positive controls, trolox (31 ± 1 μM) and α -tocopherol (50 ± 1 μM). In addition, isorhamnetin-3- O -β -D-galactopyranoside (IC 50 = 6 ± 0 μM) and astragalin (IC 50 = 6 ± 0 μM) showed similar ABTS radical-scavenging activity as transtiliroside . Based on HPLC, the content of trans -tiliroside was 9.69% in the ethyl acetate extract, 1.04% in decoction, 0.34% in 70% methanol extract, and 0.23% in infusion. None of the extracts and compounds showed α -amylase inhibition or DPPH-scavenging activity.
α -Glucosidase inhibition
Radical scavenging
Natural products
Flavonoids
trans -Tiliroside
Igdoside A-D

The Elaeagnaceae family is represented by two floral species in Turkey . One of them,
Elaeagnus angustifolia
, is a thorny shrub that can reach a height of
7 m .
E. angustifolia
is deciduous; grows naturally in Europe, Turkey , Caucasus, Syria , Iran , Afghanistan , and Pakistan ; and is widely cultivated throughout Turkey ( Güner et al., 2012 ; McKean, 1965 ).

E. angustifolia
has been identified as having numerous ethnobotanical uses by the local people of Turkey and is a potential herbal medicine for the treatment of diabetes mellitus (DM). The decoction of its leaves is consumed as a blood glucose-lowering agent ( Arıtuluk and Ezer, 2012 ) while the infusions from its flowers and leaves are consumed as diuretics and antipyretics ( Baytop, 1999 ). Previous studies have shown that
E. angustifolia
exerts antiarthritic, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antimutagenic, antinociceptive, antioxidant, antitumor, cardioprotective, gastroprotective, hypolipidemic, insecticidal, tyrosinase inhibitory, and wound-healing effects ( Carradori et al., 2020 ; Farzaei et al., 2015 ). The in vitro α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory effects of the 70% methanol extract prepared from the leaves of
E. angustifolia
have been evaluated using different methods. However, to the best of our knowledge, further studies have not been conducted to determine the effective compounds in the extract ( Saltan et al., 2017 ). By investigating the hypoglycemic effect of polysaccharides obtained from the fruit of this plant, a previous study found that these polysaccharides could potently prevent increased levels of glucose in streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice compared to control mice ( Wang et al., 2018 ). Angustifolinoid B, which is obtained from the flowers, was also found to exhibit strong α -glucosidase inhibitory activity ( Xie et al., 2020 ). Specialized metabolites, such as β -carboline alkaloids, esters, flavone glycosides, ketones, phenolic acids, phenols, phenyl ethers, polysaccharides, steroids, and terpenes, have also been identified previously in
E. angustifolia ( Farzaei et al., 2015 )
.

footnote.paragraph: Abbreviations: ABTS, 2,2 ′ -azinobis-3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid; DPPH, 1,1 ′ -diphenyl-2,2 ′ -picrylhydrazyl; HPLC, high performance liquid chromatography; NMR, nuclear magnetic resonance.
* Corresponding author. Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Ataturk University, 25240, Erzurum , Turkey .

subSection.paragraph:
DM is an endocrine disease characterized by hyperglycemia. This condition is also associated with deficient or excess insulin secretion induced by irregularities in carbohydrate, fat, and protein metabolism. Approximately 85–95% of people with DM have type II DM, which is a chronic metabolic disease caused by the inability of the body to secrete sufficient insulin or the development of insulin resistance ( Cowie and Eberhardt, 1996 ; Maritim et al., 2003 ). Defects in α -amylase, α -glucosidase, aldose reductase, angiotensin-converting enzyme, and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 play a role in the pathogenesis of type II DM ( Dey et al., 2014 ). Drugs used in a clinical setting to control DM include insulin, sulfonylureas, biguanides, thiazolidinediones, carbamoylmethyl benzoic acid, insulin-like growth factor, aldose reductase-, α -glucosidase-, and α -amylase inhibitors ( Chakrabarti and Rajagopalan, 2002 ; Cheng and Fantus, 2005 ; Inzucchi, 2002 ). In addition to using these drugs for the treatment of type II DM, other therapeutic approaches, such as inhibiting the degradation of oligosaccharides and disaccharides, can be used to reduce hyperglycemia.
α -
Glucosidase and
α -
amylase can hydrolyze carbohydrates; thus, inhibitors of these enzymes are considered useful drug candidates for type II DM therapy ( Broadhurst et al., 2000 ; Funke and Melzing, 2006 ; Matsui et al., 2001 ). Inhibitors of
α -
glucosidase and
α -
amylase delay carbohydrate digestion, thereby prolonging carbohydrate digestion time and decreasing glucose absorption rate, which lead to an decrease in postprandial plasma glucose ( Marshall and Lauda, 1975 ). Long-term use of synthetic enzyme inhibitors, such as acarbose, may cause various side effects, such as flatulence and abdominal problems ( Fred-Jaiyesimi et al., 2009 ). Natural
α -
glucosidase inhibitors have thus been presented as a better alternative to control postprandial hyperglycemia as they exhibit minor or no side effects ( Al-Azzawie and Alhamdani, 2006 ).

In this study, we investigated the antioxidant and α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities of
E. angustifolia
leaves, used to treat DM as folk medicine, and determined the compound(s) responsible for the effects. Based on our findings, among the leaf extracts, the ethyl acetate and n -butanol extracts were found to exhibit the highest α -glucosidase inhibitory effect. According to the isolation studies performed with these extracts, four undescribed flavonol glycosides, igdoside A-D ( 2–5 ), and four known glucosides ( 1, 6–8 ) were identified. The α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities of these compounds were subsequently evaluated. The extracts and isolated compounds were also assayed for their ABTS and DPPH radical-scavenging effects. Lastly, the active compound, trans -tiliroside, in the extracts was quantified using HPLC.

caption.paragraph: Table 1 α -Glucosidase inhibitory, α -amylase inhibitory, DPPH radical scavenging, and ABTS radical scavenging activities of extracts.

tableNote.paragraph: a Positive control for α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities.
b Positive controls for DPPH and ABTS radical scavenging activities.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Enzyme inhibitory activity of the leaf extract of E. angustifolia

subSection.paragraph: The 70% methanolic extract and its subfractions ( n -hexane, dichloromethane, ethyl acetate, n -butanol, and water extracts) were evaluated to determine their α -glucosidase inhibitory activity, using acarbose as the positive control. Accordingly, the 70% methanol (IC 50 = 124.80 ± 32.20 μg/mL), ethyl acetate (IC 50 = 82.05 ± 2.76 μg/ mL), and n -butanol (IC 50 = 216.49 ± 23.83 μg/mL) extracts were found to exhibit a higher activity than acarbose (IC 50 = 4212.62 ± 130.00 μg/ mL) ( Table 1 , Figures S1 and S 2 ). Thus, the ethyl acetate and n -butanol extracts were further fractionated and analyzed to determine the activity of the isolated compound(s).

emphasis.heading: 2.2. Isolation and structure determination of the undescribed compounds
in the leaf extracts of E. angustifolia

subSection.paragraph: Igdoside A ( 2 ) appeared as a yellow amorphous powder. Its molecular formula, C 37 H 46 O 18 , was determined based on the negative HRESIMS ion ( Figure S3 ) observed at m/z 777.2233 [M – H] (calcd. 778.2684). The UV spectrum (DMSO) of 2 displayed two absorption maxima (log ε ) at 283 (4.25) and 362 (4.18) nm, indicating its flavonol skeleton. The 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectra ( Table 2 , Figures S4 and S 5 ) showed the typical pattern of a flavonol acyl glycoside. Owing to the presence of two meta-coupled protons for ring A (δ 6.49 and 6.76, d, J = 2.0 Hz), an ABX system signal for ring B (δ 6.91 d, J = 8.4 Hz, 7.61 dd, J = 8.3, 2.2 Hz, and 8.04 d, J = 2.2 Hz), and one singlet signal at δ 3.97 for a methoxy group, the compound 2 aglycon was identified as isorhamnetin ( Bechlem et al., 2017 ; Ozbek et al., 2016 ). Two anomeric protons from the sugar moieties appeared at δ 5.40 ( J = 7.7 Hz) and 5.61 ( J = 1.4 Hz); these protons were found to respectively correlate with signals at δ 102.7 and 98.3 in the HMQC spectrum. COSY and HMQC ( Figures S6 and S 7) experiments led to the identification of one β -galactopyranosyl and one α -rhamnopyranosyl sugar unit. Furthermore, the 1 H-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 , Figure S4 ) revealed the presence of a quaternary methyl (δ 1.30, s), an olefinic methyl (δ 1.90, d, J = 3.4 Hz), a terminal olefin (δ 5.08, dd, J = 10.8, 1.5 Hz, δ 5.25, dd, J = 17.4, 1.5 Hz, δ 5.95, ddd, J = 17.4, 10.8, 1.5 Hz), an olefinic proton (δ 6.96, m), and two methylene protons (δ 1.67 and 2.30, m). These protons correlated with signals at δ 11.1 and 26.4 for methyl carbons; δ 23.2, 40.3, and 111.0 for methylene carbons; and δ 143.2 and 144.5 for methyn carbons. In addition, two quaternary carbons (δ 127.2 and 72.2) and one ester carbon (δ 168.1) are seen in the 13 C-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 , Figure S5 ), and δ 6.96 (m) and 1.90 (d, J = 3.4) were found to correlate with δ 168.1. These findings suggest that this compound is an ester of the monoterpenoid, α,β -unsaturated carboxylic acid. The correlations between H-1 (δ 5.40) of galactose and C-3 of aglycone (δ 134.2), H-1 of rhamnose (δ 5.61) and C-7 of aglycone (δ 161.9), and H-4 of rhamnose (δ 5.18) and C-1 of acyl (δ 168.0) were detected in the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 and S 8) of 2 . As a result of these interactions, β -D-Gal-(1 → 3)-Agl, α -L-Rham-(1 → 7)-Agl, and Acyl-(1 → 4)- α -L-Rham linkages were detected. Compound 2 was thus identified as isorhamnetin-3- O -β -D-galactopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2, 7-octadienoyl-(1 → 4)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside A).

Igdoside B ( 3 ) appeared as a yellow amorphous powder. Its molecular formula, C 44 H 56 O 22 , was determined based on the positive HRESIMS ion (Figure S 9) observed at m/z 935.31984 [M – H] + (calcd. 936.3263). The UV spectrum (DMSO) of 3 showed two absorption maxima (log ε ) at 278 (4.01) and 359 (4.30) nm, indicating its flavonol skeleton. By comparing the MS and NMR data of 3 ( Table 2 , Figures S 9- S 14) to those of 2 , an additional rhamnose unit and a different linkage of acyl monoterpene to rhamnose in 3 were identified. In addition, H-3 of rhamnose was correlated with the ester carbon (δ 167.1) and H-1 of the second rhamnose was linked to C-6 (65.7) of galactose ( Fig. 2 ). Compound 3 was thus identified as isorhamnetin-3- O-α -L-rhamnopyranosyl-(1 → 6)- β -D-galactopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 3)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside B).

Igdoside C ( 4 ) was obtained as a yellow amorphous powder. Based on the positive HRESIMS ion (Figure S 15) observed at m/z 1129.37324 [M + H] + (calcd. 1128.369), its molecular formula was determined to be C 54 H 64 O 26 . The UV spectrum (DMSO) of 4 showed two absorption maxima (log ε ) at 298 (3.81) and 338 (4.09) nm, indicating its flavonol skeleton. By comparing the MS and NMR data of 4 ( Table 2 , Figures S 15- S 20) to those of 3 , glucose and feruloyl groups were identified. Three anomeric protons from the sugar moieties appeared at δ 4.60 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 5.72 (d, J = 7.5 Hz), and 5.55 (bs); these protons were found to respectively correlate with signals at δ 104.5, 99.0, and 98.5 in the HMQC spectrum (Figure S 19). COSY and HMQC (Figures S 18 and S 19) experiments using compound 4 led to the identification of one β -glucopyranosyl, one β -galactopyranosyl, and one α -rhamnopyranosyl sugar unit. In addition to other proton signals of the compound, the 1 H-NMR spectrum (Figure S 16) indicated a methoxy group at δ 3.73 (s); aromatic protons as an ABX system at δ 6.70 (d, J = 8.1 Hz), 6.85 (dd, J = 8.2 and 1.5 Hz), and 7.08 (d, J = 1.8 Hz); and two protons at δ 6.14 and 7.31 (d, J = 15.8 Hz) of a trans -double bond, ultimately confirming the feruloyl moiety. In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 and S 20) of 4 , which had the same correlations found in compound 3 , the following correlations were observed: H-1 glu (δ 4.60) with C-3 (δ 133.7), H-2 glu (δ 3.80) with C-1 gal (δ 99.0), and H-6 gal (δ 4.18 and 4.23) with C-9 fer (166.8). Based on these findings, compound 4 was identified as isorhamnetin-3- O -(6 ′′′ - O -trans - feruloyl)- β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 2) -β -D-glucopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6- dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 3)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside C).

Igdoside D ( 5 ) was obtained as a yellow amorphous powder. Based on the positive HRESIMS ion (Figure S 21) observed at m/z 922.29953 [M-(Glucose+ Galactose+ Methoxy)] + (calcd. 1276.427), its molecular formula was identified as C 56 H 76 O 33 . The UV spectrum (DMSO) of 5 showed two absorption maxima (log ε ) at 278 (4.02) and 360 (4.21) nm, indicating its flavonol skeleton. Compound 5 was identified to be composed of isorhamnetin aglycone, five sugar units, and an acyl group, as previously described. In the 1 H-NMR spectrum ( Table 2 , Figure S 22), five anomeric protons [δ 5.66 (d, J = 7.6 Hz), 5.61 (d, J = 8.0 Hz), 5.69 (bs), 4.59 (d, J = 7.4 Hz), 4.57 (d, J = 5.7 Hz)] were observed. Based on the 1D and 2D-NMR data (Figures S 22- S 26), the sugar units were determined to be two β -galactopyranose, two β -glucopyranose, and one α -rhamnopyranose unit. In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 and S 26), the correlations from H-1 of rhamnose (δ 5.69) to C-7 of aglycone (δ 161.7), H-1 of galactose-2 (δ 5.61) to C-3 of rhamnose (δ 73.7), H-2 of rhamnose (δ 4.06) to C-1 of acyl (δ 167.5), H-1 of glucose-1 (δ 4.59) to C-3 of aglycone (δ 133.7), H-2 of glucose-1 (δ 3.85) to C-1 of glucose-2 (δ 104.6), and H-2 of glucose-2 (δ 3.76) to C-1 of galactose-1 (δ 98.8) suggested the linkages β -D-Glu 1 -(1 → 3)-Agl, β -D-Glu 2 -(1 → 2)- β -D-Glu 1 , β -D-Gal 1 -(1 → 2)- β -D-Glu 2 , α -L-Rham-(1 → 7)-Agl, Acyl-(1 → 2)- α -L-Rham, and β -D-Gal 2 -(1 → 3)- α -L-Rham, respectively. Therefore, compound 5 was identified as isorhamnetin-3- O -β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 2)- β -D-glucopyranosyl-(1 → 2)- β -D-glucopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6- dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 2)]-[ β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 3)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside D).

caption.paragraph: 1 H-NMR (400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (100 MHz) data of compounds 2–5 in DMSO d (δ in ppm, J in Hz). ‑ 6
Fig. 2. Key HMBC correlations of compounds 2–5.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Enzyme inhibitory activities of the isolated compounds

subSection.paragraph: The isolated compounds were assessed to determine their α -glucosidase inhibitory activities; acarbose was used as the positive control (IC 50 = 6561 ± 207 μM). Compound 1 ( trans -tiliroside) was the only compound to exhibit α -glucosidase inhibitory activity (IC 50 = 2128 ± 63 μM) ( Table 3 , Fig. 3 and S 1 ). All extracts and compounds were also evaluated to determine their α -amylase inhibitory activity compared to that of acarbose (IC 50 = 1930 ± 46 μM), but none of them were effective enzyme inhibitors ( Tables 1 and 3 , Fig. 4 , S 27 and S 28). As stated in a previous report, compounds glycosylated at the C-3 and/or C-7 position ( Fig. 1 ) do not exhibit α -amylase inhibitory activity ( Cao and Chen, 2012 ).

Compound 1 ( trans -tiliroside) showed high α -glucosidase inhibition, whereas compound 7 (astragalin) had no effect ( Table 3 , Fig. 3 ). Although both compounds have a kaempferol unit, the effect exhibited by compound 1 could be attributed to the linkage of trans -coumaroyl with the C-6 of glucose ( Cao and Chen, 2012 ). Such findings are supported by those of Qin et al. (2011) . The anti-glycation effect of trans --tiliroside, the major compound of
E. angustifolia
flowers, was previously evaluated. Aminoguanidine (the comparative standard) displayed an anti-glycation effect of 55.3%, while 37.5 μg/mL of trans -tiliroside displayed an effect of 78.9% ( Jia et al., 2019 ). trans -Tiliroside has also been isolated from
Potentilla chinensis
and
Allium cepa
and its hypoglycemic effect has been determined. Accordingly, a significant anti-hyperglycemic effect was identified based on the reduction in blood glucose in diabetic rats ( Ikechukwu and Ifeanyi, 2016 ; Qiao et al., 2011 ).

caption.paragraph: Table 3 α -Glucosidase inhibitory, α -amylase inhibitory, DPPH radical scavenging, and ABTS radical scavenging activities of isolated compounds.

tableNote.paragraph: a Positive control for α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities.
b Positive controls for DPPH and ABTS radical scavenging activities.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Concentration-response curves of the α -glucosidase inhibitory activity of isolated compounds.
Fig. 4. Concentration-response curves of the α -amylase inhibitory activity of isolated compounds.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. Antioxidant capacity of the extracts and isolated compounds

subSection.paragraph: All extracts and compounds were evaluated for their antioxidant capacity using ABTS and DPPH radical-scavenging assays. Trolox and α -tocopherol were used as positive controls in both assays. The extracts and compounds were found to be less effective than trolox (IC 50 = 67 ± 2 μM) and α -tocopherol (IC 50 = 95 ± 3 μM) in the DPPH radical-scavenging assay ( Tables 1 and 3 , Fig. 5 , S 29 and S 30). However, when the extracts were compared to trolox (IC 50 = 7.65 ± 0.16 μg/mL) and α -tocopherol (IC 50 = 21.34 ± 0.48 μg/mL) in the ABTS radical-scavenging assay, the ethyl acetate extract (IC 50 = 13.79 ± 0.14 μg/ mL) had a higher effect than α -tocopherol, whereas the n -butanol extract (IC 50 = 23.98 ± 0.34 μg/mL) displayed an effect similar to that of the standard compounds ( Table 1 , Figures S 31 and S 32). When the isolated compounds were compared to trolox (IC 50 = 31 ± 1 μM) and α -tocopherol (IC 50 = 50 ± 1 μM), all were found to exhibit higher ABTS radical-scavenging effects than the standards ( Table 3 , Fig. 6 and S 31).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Concentration-response curves of the DPPH radical scavenging capacity of isolated compounds.

subSection.paragraph: Consistent with the results of the α -glucosidase enzyme-inhibition assay, compound 1 ( trans -tiliroside) was found to be most effective in scavenging ABTS radicals ( Table 3 , Fig. 6 ), likely owing to the presence of kaempferol and trans -coumaric acid in its structure ( Fig. 1 ). Methoxylation of the B ring was found to decrease this effect, whereas the presence of phenolic acid in the structure increased the effect ( Yordi et al., 2012 ). trans -Tiliroside ( 1 ) was previously shown to possess exhibit ABTS radical-scavenging activity, but was found to be ineffective in scavenging DPPH radicals, as observed in our study ( Mekhelfi et al., 2016 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Concentration-response curves of the ABTS radical scavenging capacity of isolated compounds.

heading.emphasis: 2.5. Quantification of the active compound trans-tiliroside by HPLC

subSection.paragraph:
The concentration of trans-tiliroside in the 70% methanol extract, ethyl acetate extract (active subfraction), decoction, and infusion was determined using HPLC (g/ 100 g dry extract for extracts and g/ 100 g dry leaves for decoction and infusion). The retention time of trans -tiliroside was 38.405 min. Its concentration in the 70% methanol extract, ethyl acetate extract, decoction, and infusion was 0.34%, 9.69%, 1.04%, and 0.23%, respectively. The HPLC chromatograms of pure trans -tiliroside and the 70% methanol and ethyl acetate extracts, decoction, and infusion of
E. angustifolia
are presented in Figure S 33. The 70% methanol extract is a suitable solvent for extracting all metabolites, whereas ethyl acetate is a semi-polar solvent that can extract both polar and non-polar components. Owing to the fractionation process, the quantity of compounds extracted by ethyl acetate was higher than that obtained using 70% methanol. Therefore, the concentration of trans -tiliroside was higher in the ethyl acetate extract than in the 70% methanol extract. Further, the concentration of trans -tiliroside was higher in the decoction than in the infusion due to the reflux process. The traditional antidiabetic activity of
E. angustifolia
leaves can be ascribed to the presence of trans -tiliroside in decoctions and infusions.

To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study wherein a potent α -glucosidase inhibitor was isolated from the leaves of
E. angustifolia .
Notably, the leaf extracts of ethyl acetate and n -butanol exhibited the highest α -glucosidase inhibitory effects. Upon purification of these extracts, four undescribed flavonol glycosides, igdoside A-D ( 2-5 ), and four known glucosides, namely trans -tiliroside ( 1 ), isorhamnetin-3- O - β -D-galactopyranoside ( 6 ), astragalin ( 7 ), and isorhamnetin-3- O -β -Dgalactopyranosyl-7- O -α -L-rhamnopyranoside ( 8 ), were identified. The undescribed compounds were isorhamnetin-3- O -β -D-galactopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 4)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside A, 2 ), isorhamnetin-3- O-α -L-rhamnopyranosyl-(1 → 6)- β -D-galactopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 3)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside B, 3 ), isorhamnetin-3- O -(6 ′′′ - O -trans -feruloyl)- β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 2) -β -D-glucopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 3)]- α -Lrhamnopyranoside (igdoside C, 4 ), and isorhamnetin-3- O -β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 2)- β -D-glucopyranosyl-(1 → 2)- β -D-glucopyranosyl-7- O -[2,6-dimethyl-6-hydroxy-2,7-octadienoyl-(1 → 2)]-[ β -D-galactopyranosyl-(1 → 3)]- α -L-rhamnopyranoside (igdoside D, 5 ). After the isolated compounds were assessed to determine their α -glucosidase and α -amylase inhibitory activities, their antioxidant activities against ABTS and DPPH radicals were also assessed. Based on the findings, transtiliroside is responsible for the α -glucosidase inhibitory and antioxidant effects of
E. angustifolia
as well as its strong α -glucosidase inhibitory and ABTS radical-scavenging activities. In addition, isorhamnetin-3- O -β -Dgalactopyranoside and astragalin showed similar ABTS radical-scavenging activity as trans -tiliroside. Because infusions and decoctions prepared from the leaves of
E. angustifolia
have been used traditionally, trans -tiliroside levels in both extracts and the active extracts were determined. Based on HPLC, the highest concentration of trans -tiliroside (9.69%) was present in the ethyl acetate extract followed by the decoction (1.04%), 70% methanol extract (0.34%), and infusion (0.23%). Collectively, these findings suggest the potential of
E. angustifolia
and trans -tiliroside ( 1 ) as novel therapeutic candidates and herbal medicines for the treatment of type II DM.

1D ( 1 H-NMR, 13 C-NMR, and DEPT) and 2D (COSY, HMQC, and HMBC) NMR spectra were derived using Varian Mercury Plus (400 MHz for 1 H-NMR and 100 MHz for 13 C-NMR) spectrometers, with TMS as an internal standard. These instruments were accessed in the Faculty of Science at Ataturk University. HRESIMS data were recorded using an Agilent 6530 Accurate-Mass apparatus and AB Sciex TripleTOF 4600 (Agilent Technologies Inc., California , USA ) at the Ataturk University East Anatolia High Technology Application and Research Center (DAYTAM). The UV spectra were obtained using a Thermo Scientific Multiscan Go UV–Vis spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, California , USA ). The specific optical rotations of compounds 2–5 were measured using a Bellingham & Stanley ADP 220 589 nm polarimeter (Bellingham & Stanley Ltd., Tunbridge Wells, United Kingdom ) equipped with an LED light at the Faculty of Science, Ataturk University. Open column chromatography (CC) was carried out using silica gel 60 ( 0.063–0.2 mm ) (Merck, Germany ), Sephadex LH-20, polyamide 6 (Fluka, Switzerland ), and RP-18 reverse-phase silica gel (LiChroprep RP-18, 25–40 μm (Merck, Germany ) columns. Semi-preparative HPLC was performed using an Agilent 1260 liquid chromatograph (Agilent Technologies Inc.) equipped with Supelco-Ascentis RP Amide (250 × 10 mm , 5 μm) and ACE 5 C18 (250 × 7.75 mm ) columns. The purities and retention times (Rt) of the isolated compounds were determined using HPLC at 350 nm [acetonitrile (ACN):0.2% formic acid (FA) (0:100 → 40:60, v/v), flow rate of 0.3 mL/min, Supelco Ascentis Express RP-Amide (100 × 2.1 mm , 2.7 μm)]. Solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich ( USA ). TLC was performed using precoated silica gel 60 F 254 plates (Merck), and the spots were visualized by spraying with 1% vanillin solution in concentrated sulfuric acid, followed by heating at 110 ◦ C. Dinitrosalicylic acid, α -glucosidase from
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
( Type 1, lyophilized powder), α -amylase (from porcine pancreas), acarbose, p -nitrophenol- α -D-glucopyranoside, ABTS, DPPH, trolox, and α -tocopherol from Sigma-Aldrich ( USA ) were used for bioactivity assays.

In the early summer of June 2016 , the leaves of
Elaeagnus angustifolia L
. ( Elaeagnaceae ) were collected in Ormanagzı Village, Olur, Erzurum City, Turkey (
40 ◦ 46 ′ 07.00 ′′ N
,
42 ◦ 05 ′ 09.96 ′′ E
). The plant material was authenticated by the Forest Engineer, Mehmet ONAL ¨, MSc. A voucher specimen (No. AUEF 1349) was deposited at the Biodiversity Application and Research Center, Ataturk University, Erzurum , Turkey .

E. angustifolia
leaves ( 800 g ) were dried in the open air in a shaded location, powdered, and allowed to macerate overnight in 2 L of 70% methanol. The medicinal plants were generally used following preparation with water and three rounds of extraction for 3 h at 40 ◦ C using a mantle heater and reflux cooler. The filtered extracts were concentrated to dryness in a rotary evaporator at 40 ◦ C and 120 rpm. The 70% methanol extract ( 181.5 g ) in water was fractionated using n -hexane (2 × 500 mL), dichloromethane (4 × 500 mL), ethyl acetate (3 × 500 mL), and n -butanol (6 × 500 mL). Thereafter, the extracts and remaining aqueous phases were concentrated. After concentrating to dryness, 0.2, 87.4, 12.0, 34.1, and 40.9 g of extracts were obtained from the n -hexane, dichloromethane, ethyl acetate, n -butanol, and water fractions, respectively.

The ethyl acetate extract ( 3 g of total extract) was fractionated using silica gel CC (70–230 mesh, 337 g ) with toluene:CHCl 3 :MeOH (5:75:20, v/v/v) to yield two fractions, Fr. A and Fr. B. Fr. A ( 0.48 g ) was further fractionated using semi-preparative HPLC (RP-Amide column, 250 × 10 mm , 5 μm) using a suitable method [ACN:0.2% FA (20:80 → 48:52, v/v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to obtain subfractions Frs. A.1–5. Fr. A.5 ( 138.23 mg ) was purified using a Sephadex LH-20 CC ( 50 g , MeOH), followed by RP-18 CC ( 40 g ) with a H 2 O:MeOH (100:0 → 0:100, v/v) gradient system to yield compound 1 ( 12.8 mg ). Based on HPLC, the purity of compound 1 was determined to be 96.51% and its Rt was 38.405 min. Fr. B ( 0.26 g ) was further fractionated using semi-preparative HPLC [ACN:0.2% FA (30:70 → 38:62 v/v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to obtain four subfractions, Frs. B.1–4. Fr. B.4 ( 39.85 mg ) was purified using Sephadex LH-20 CC ( 50 g , MeOH) followed by RP-18 CC ( 40 g ) with a H 2 O:MeOH (100:0 → 0:100, v/v) gradient system to yield compound 2 ( 11 mg ). The purity of compound 2 was determined to be 97.94% using HPLC, with a Rt of 31.297 min.

The ethyl acetate extract ( 9 g of total extract) was fractionated using polyamide CC ( 40 g ) with H 2 O:MeOH (100:0 → 30:70, v/v) to yield three fractions, Frs. A–C. Fr. B ( 3.34 g ) was further fractionated via silica gel CC ( 40 g ) with CH 2 Cl 2 :MeOH (100:0 → 20:80, v/v) to obtain three subfractions, Frs. B.1–3. Fr. B.1 ( 583.60 mg ) was further fractionated using silica gel CC ( 17 g ) with a CH 2 Cl 2 :MeOH:H 2 O (90:10:1, v/v/v) solvent system to yield two subfractions, Fr. B.1.1 ( 96.30 mg ) and Fr. B.1.2 ( 319.30 mg ). Fr. B.1.2 ( 319.30 mg ) was purified using semi-preparative HPLC [ACN:0.2% FA (10:90 → 46:54 v/v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to obtain compound 6 ( 5.70 mg ) and compound 7 ( 12.80 mg ). Using HPLC ( 350 nm ), the purities of compounds 6 and 7 were determined to be 96.41% (Rt = 37.779 min) and 95.28% (Rt = 36.673 min), respectively. Fr. B.3 ( 833.10 mg ) was fractionated using silica gel CC ( 17 g ) and CH 2 Cl 2 :MeOH:H 2 O (90:10:1, v/v/v) as a solvent system to yield four subfractions, Frs. B.3.1 (28.00 mg), Fr. B.3.2 (295.00 mg), Fr. B.3.3 ( 143.10 mg ), and Fr. B.3.4 ( 104.50 mg ). Fr. B.3.2 (295.00 mg) was purified using semi-preparative HPLC [ACN:0.2% FA (10:90 → 46:54 v/v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to yield compound 3 ( 49.90 mg ) and compound 4 ( 40.10 mg ). Fr. B.3.4 ( 104.50 mg ) was also purified using semi-preparative HPLC [ACN:0.2% FA (10:90 → 46:54 v/ v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to yield compound 5 ( 19.50 mg ). Using HPLC ( 350 nm ), the purities of compounds 3–5 were determined to be 96.44% (Rt = 45.656 min), 97.30% (Rt = 46.991 min), and 96.63% (Rt = 39.445 min), respectively.

The n -butanol extract (20.00 g) was fractionated using silica gel CC (70–230 mesh, 100 g ) and CH 2 Cl 2 :MeOH (100:0 → 0:100 v/v) to yield Frs. A and B. Fr. A ( 4.20 g ) was further fractionated using RP-18 CC ( 40 g ) and a H 2 O:MeOH (100:0 → 0:100, v/v) gradient system to yield two subfractions, Frs. A.1 and A.2. Fr. A.1 ( 1.30 g ) was purified using Sephadex LH-20 CC ( 50 g , MeOH) to yield three subfractions, Fr. A.1.1 ( 711.80 mg ), Fr. A.1.2 ( 58.50 mg ), and Fr. A.1.3 ( 18.60 mg ). Fr. A.1.2 ( 58.50 mg ) was further purified using semi-preparative HPLC [C18 column, 250 × 7.75 mm , 5 μm, MeOH:0.2% FA (30:70 → 80:20, v/v), flow rate = 5 mL/min] to obtain compound 8 ( 8.8 mg ). Using HPLC, the purity of compound 8 was determined to be 96.93% and was found to have a Rt of 30.956 min.

Yellow amorphous powder; [α] D 24 84.5 (c 1.03, MeOH); UV (DMSO) λ max (log ε ): 283 (4.25), 362 (4.18) nm; for 1 H-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 100 MHz) spectroscopic data, Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z : 777.2233 [M – H] (calcd. for C 37 H 46 O 18 , 778.2684).

Yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 24 72.6 ( c 1.06, MeOH); UV (DMSO) λ max (log ε ): 278 (4.01), 359 (4.30) nm; for 1 H-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 100 MHz) spectroscopic data, Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z : 935.31984 [M – H] + (calcd. for C 44 H 56 O 22 , 936.3263).

Yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 24 58.3 ( c 1.03, MeOH); UV (DMSO) λ max (log ε ): 298 (3.81), 338 (4.09) nm; for 1 H-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 100 MHz) spectroscopic data, Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z : 1129.37324 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 54 H 64 O 26 , 1128.369).

Yellow amorphous powder; [ α ] D 24 73.6 ( c 0.91, MeOH); UV (DMSO) λ max (log ε ): 278 (4.02), 360 (4.21) nm; for 1 H-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 400 MHz) and 13 C-NMR (DMSO ‑d 6 , 100 MHz) spectroscopic data, Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z : 922.29953 [M-(Glucose+ Galactose+ Methoxy)] + (calcd. for C 56 H 76 O 33 , 1276.427).

The inhibitory effect on α -glucosidase was determined according to the method of Bachhawat et al. (2011) , with slight modifications ( Güvenalp et al., 2017 ). All samples (20 μL), enzyme solution (10 μL, 1 U/mL), and potassium phosphate buffer (50 μL, 50 mM, pH 6.9) were mixed in a 96-well plate and incubated at 37 ◦ C for 5 min. To initiate the reaction, the substrate, p -nitrophenyl- α -D-glucopyranoside (20 μL, 3 mM), was added to each well. The mixtures were subsequently incubated at 37 ◦ C for 30 min. Thereafter, to quench the reaction, 0.1 M sodium carbonate (50 μL) was added to each well. Acarbose was used as a positive control. The amount of p -nitrophenol was measured using a 96-well microplate reader at 405 nm . Each assay was performed in triplicate for all samples. The percentage inhibition of all samples was calculated using the following equation:
Inhibition(%) = (1 ΔA 405 sample / ΔA 405 control) × 100

The inhibitory effect on α -amylase was determined according to the method of Nampoothiri et al. (2011) , with slight modifications ( Güvenalp et al., 2017 ). All samples (100 μL) and 1% starch solution (100 μL) in 20 mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 6.9 containing 6 mM sodium chloride) were incubated at 25 ◦ C for 10 min in a 24-well microplate. After incubation, 100 μL α -amylase solution ( 0.5 mg /mL) was added to each well and the reaction mixtures were incubated at 25 ◦ C for 10 min. The reaction was subsequently terminated by the addition of dinitrosalicylic acid color reagent (200 μL). After the microplate was heated in a boiling water bath for 5 min and cooled to 25 ◦ C, 50 μL was removed from each well and transferred to a 96-well microplate. The reaction mixture was diluted by the addition of 200 μL distilled water, and the absorbance at 540 nm was measured. Acarbose was used as the positive control. Each assay was performed in triplicate for all samples. The percentage inhibition of all samples was calculated using the following equation:
Inhibition (%) = (1 ΔA 540 sample / ΔA 540 control) × 100

The DPPH radical-scavenging activity was evaluated according to the method of Blois (1958) . All samples (210 μL) and DPPH solution (70 μL, 1 mM) were transferred to the respective microplate wells. The mixture was shaken for approximately 1 min and incubated for 30 min at room temperature in the dark. The absorbance of all samples was recorded at 517 nm against ethanol. α -Tocopherol and trolox were used as positive controls. Each assay was performed in triplicate for all samples. The percentage radical scavenging capacity of all samples was calculated using the following equation:
Radical scavenging capacity(%) = (1 ΔA 517 sample / ΔA 517 control) × 100

The ABTS radical-scavenging activity was determined according to the method of Re et al. (1999) . Briefly, 2 mM of ABTS solution was prepared. Thereafter, ABTS free radicals were generated via the addition of an equal volume of 2.45 mM potassium persulfate. All samples (140 μL) and ABTS solution (100 μL) were transferred to the wells and shaken for 1 min. At the end of the 30-min incubation period, the absorbances at 734 nm were recorded. The absorbance value of the control sample at 734 nm was 0.700 ± 0.025. α -Tocopherol and trolox were used as positive controls. Each assay was performed in triplicate for all samples. The percentage radical scavenging capacity of all samples was calculated using the following equation:
Radical scavenging capacity (%) = (1 ΔA 734 sample / ΔA 734 control) × 100

To evaluate the role of the active compounds, the leaves of
E. angustifolia
, used traditionally in the management of DM, were used to prepare an infusion ( 0.5 g leaves in 50 mL water, 15 min) and a decoction ( 0.5 g leaves in 50 mL water, 30 min) ( European Medicines Agency, 2010 ). HPLC was used to determine the concentrations of trans -tiliroside in the 70% methanol extract, ethyl acetate extract, decoction, and infusion using a Supelco Ascentis Express RP-Amide column (100 × 2.1 mm , 2.7 μm) as the stationary phase. The column temperature was maintained at 40 ◦ C. The mobile phase consisted of a gradient system of ACN:0.2% FA (0:100 → 40:60, v/v) at a flow rate of 0.3 mL/min and a run time of 50 min. The injection volume was 20 μL. The absorbance of the eluent was monitored at 254 nm .

Standard solutions of trans -tiliroside (six dilutions ranging from 10 to 125 μg/mL) were prepared. Each standard solution was injected three times. A calibration curve was plotted using the peak areas and concentrations. The linear regression equation was y = 3761.5x + 11048, with a correlation coefficient (R) of 0.9973. The limit of detection (LOD: 0.5 μg/mL) and limit of quantification (LOQ: 1.5 μg/mL) were determined based on the signal-to-noise ( S /N) ratio. Specifically, a series of diluted standard solutions were analyzed, and ratios of 3 and 10 ( S /N) were obtained and expressed in concentrations equivalent to the ratios.

All experiments were performed in triplicate. Kruskal-Wallis test was used to determine statistical significance. Results were analyzed using SPSS (IBM SPSS Statistics 20, IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY, USA ) at the significance level of P = 0.05. The percent inhibition and IC 50 value data for extracts and compounds are presented as means ± standard deviation.

The authors would also like to thank Prof. Dr. Cavit Kazaz (Ataturk University) for obtaining the NMR spectra of the compounds and Prof. Dr. Hamdullah Kılıç (Ataturk University) for obtaining the specific optical rotations of the compounds.
